{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Bowling techniques sidebar |expanded=all}} In the sport of [[cricket]], a '''bouncer''' (or '''bumper''') is a type of [[delivery (cricket)|delivery]], usually [[bowling (cricket)|bowled]] by a fast [[bowler (cricket)|bowler]].
==Usage== Bouncers are used to drive the batsman back on to his back foot if he has been freely playing front foot scoring shots, such as drives. To this end, bouncers are usually directed more or less at the [[line and length|line]] of the batsman's body. Aiming at the batsman is legal provided the [[bouncing ball|ball bounces]] on the pitch; or upon reaching the batsman, the ball is below the batsman's waist. Aiming at the batsman's head without bouncing on the pitch, known as a [[beamer (cricket)|beamer]], is illegal.
[[File:Playing a hook shot.jpg|thumb|left|260px|A batsman attempting to play a [[Batting (cricket)#Pull and hook|hook shot]] against a bouncer.]] A batsman may play a bouncer in either a defensive or an attacking way. If the batsman plays it defensively he aims primarily to avoid getting out, and secondarily to avoid being hit by the ball. For a head-high bouncer, these goals are achieved most easily by ducking under the ball. If the ball is at chest height, the batsman's best defence is to move on to his back foot, raise his bat vertically to chest height, and attempt to block the ball and direct it downwards to the pitch so as to avoid presenting a catch to a fielder. Sometimes the batsman will need to jump into the air to gain the necessary height to defend with the bat. He may also sway out of the way. Given these approaches, the bowler can hope to both intimidate the batsman somewhat, and possibly have the ball deflect off the bat at an awkward angle and produce a catch for a nearby fielder. A bouncer ball is not valid if the ball is above the marks height before touching ground (the mark height is 8ft) that's mean when the bowler is bowling the ball the bowl should not exceed the 8 feet of height before touching ground, if it is above the mark level the ball will be declared No ball and the rule may change if the bowler height is above 6ft 5inch it will be increase 1/2 feet as height increase and the ball release as high intentionally it would be categorized as unfair delivery. That may be concern as objectionable delivery. The bowler that throw convective delivery as bouncer may lead to match fine or can be temporary ban for not obeying the cricket rule and tried to unfollow the rules. [[File:Cricket_delivery_lengths_en.svg|left|thumb|Bouncer in purple.]]
Conversely, the bouncer can be a very productive ball for the batsman, if he plays it in an attacking manner. The shot that is used to attack the bouncer is the [[Batting (cricket)#Pull and hook|hook shot]]. To play the hook shot the batsman moves his back foot backwards and towards the off side as the ball is being delivered. As the ball approaches, the batsman swivels from facing the off side to facing the leg side, while holding the bat horizontally. The batsman's aim is to hit the ball at high speed towards, into or over the leg side boundary. However, despite their run-scoring potential, hook, shots frequently lead to wickets falling, particularly through balls hitting the top edge of the bat and being caught by leg side fielders. However, if the bouncer is misdirected by the bowler, and reaches the batsman on the off side of his wicket, the cut, uppercut or late cut can be played, either with the intention of guiding the ball along the ground, through a gap in the field setting, or over the infield for four or six.
There is an unspoken agreement, particularly in the time before the widespread use of batting helmets, that fast bowlers will not bowl bouncers at each other, because less skilled batsmen are less likely to effectively defend and therefore more likely to be struck. Breaking of this rule can lead to 'bouncer wars' – that is, the targeted bowler engaging in retaliatory hostile short-pitched bowling at his opponent during the following innings.
==ICC rules== Because of the potential danger to batsmen of being hit and to stop bowlers bowling bouncers all the time, there are Laws in the [[Laws of Cricket]] governing how frequently a bowler may bowl bouncers, as well as how many fielders may field backward of square leg. These laws take into account the relative skill of the batsmen.
During the 1970s to 1980s, bouncers were used as part of a team's intimidatory tactics, especially by the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies team]]. In 1991, the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) introduced a "one bouncer per batsman per over" rule in an attempt to discourage use of intimidation. However, the ruling was not well received by players and umpires alike, with English [[Umpire (cricket)|umpire]] [[Dickie Bird]] describing it as "farcical" as he felt that calling intimidatory tactics should be left to the umpire.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bird wants end to bouncer rule|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket-bird-wants-end-to-bouncer-rule-1397077.html|publisher=[[The Independent|independent.co.uk]]|date=28 February 1994}}</ref> The ICC changed it to two bouncers per over in 1994, with a two-run no-ball penalty (rather than one-run no-ball) if the bowler exceeded two bouncers an over.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket-icc-allows-extra-bouncer-per-over-lords-changes-intimidatory-bowling-rule-1412275.html|title=Cricket: ICC allows extra bouncer per over: Lord's changes|author=MARTIN JOHNSON, Cricket Correspondent|date=6 July 1994|work=The Independent}}</ref> One Day International cricket allowed one bouncer per over in 2001 (and a one-run no-ball in case a bowler exceeded the limit).<ref>{{cite web|title=Cricket's Turning Points: The bouncer rule|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/491190.html|publisher=[[Cricinfo]]}}</ref>
On 29 October 2012 the ICC increased the number of bouncers that could be bowled during a One Day International to two.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.wisdenindia.com/cricket-news/icc-paves-day-night-tests/32709| title=ICC paves way for Day-Night Tests| publisher=Wisden India| date=29 October 2012| access-date=30 October 2012| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630231143/http://www.wisdenindia.com/cricket-news/icc-paves-day-night-tests/32709#| archive-date=30 June 2015| dead-url=yes| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The number of bouncers per over allowed in T20s was kept to one.
==Controversies== Fast leg theory, the deliberate and sustained bowling of bouncers aimed at the body, coupled with a cordon of legside catching fieldsmen to catch deflections, was a tactic used by [[English cricket team|England]] against [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] in 1932/33, dubbed the [[Bodyline]] series by the Australians. This controversial tactic caused the [[Laws of Cricket]] to be reformed to prevent any recurrence.
In 1954–55 in Sydney,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/21/21372.html|title=The Home of CricketArchive|publisher=}}</ref> England fast bowler [[Frank Tyson]] bowled bouncers at Australian [[Ray Lindwall]], who returned the favour by hospitalising Tyson with one of his own. An angry Tyson returned with a large lump on his head and took 6/85 in the second innings to give England a 38-run victory.
In 1994 at the Oval<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/59/59371.html|title=The Home of CricketArchive|publisher=}}</ref> [[Devon Malcolm]] was hit on the helmet by a bouncer from [[Fanie de Villiers]]. The incensed Malcolm told the South Africans "You guys are history" and took apart their second innings with 9/57.
==Injuries and deaths caused by bouncers== [[File:Justin_Langer_Portrait.jpg|thumb|[[Justin Langer]] spent time in hospital in 2006 after being struck in the head by a bouncer]] The bouncer is an aggressive delivery and the very nature of the delivery by a fast bowler and aimed at the head can lead to batsmen being hit in the chest, neck or head.
In 1962, Indian captain [[Nari Contractor]] was hit above his right ear by a [[Charlie Griffith]] bouncer which resulted in severe loss of blood and left Contractor critically ill. He regained full consciousness after six days and returned to first-class cricket ten months later.<ref>{{cite web|title=The bouncer that ended a career|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/807661.html|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref>
In 2006, Australian opener [[Justin Langer]], was struck on the head in his 100th Test from a bouncer from [[Makhaya Ntini]] and hospitalised. In 2008 [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] batsman [[Shivnarine Chanderpaul]] was knocked out for several minutes after being hit by a bouncer from Australian [[Fast bowling|fast bowler]] [[Brett Lee]] during a test match.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brett Lee bumper KO's runmaker Chanderpaul|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/cricket/lee-bumper-kos-runmaker/story-e6frepmo-1111116438755|newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]]|date=26 May 2008}}</ref> [[Shoaib Akhtar]] injured both [[Gary Kirsten]] (2003) and [[Brian Lara]] (2004) with fast bouncers. Both batsmen had to be taken off the field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/video_audio/638803.html|title=My XI : Shoaib Akhtar – 'Undoubtedly the quickest, the meanest' – Cricket videos, MP3, podcasts, cricket audio – ESPN Cricinfo|work=Cricinfo}}</ref>
In November 2014, Australian cricketer [[Phillip Hughes]] was knocked unconscious by a bouncer from [[Sean Abbott]], which hit the side of his head, between the grille and shell of his helmet, during a [[Sheffield Shield]] match.<ref name=abc-hughes-scg>{{cite news |title=Phillip Hughes in critical condition following surgery after being knocked out by bouncer in Sheffield Shield match |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-11-25/test-aspirant-phillip-hughes-in-critical-condition-after-surgery/5916844 |accessdate=25 November 2014 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=25 November 2014}}</ref> He was taken to hospital in a critical condition, suffering from a [[subarachnoid haemorrhage]], but died from his injuries two days later, never having regained consciousness.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/30219440|title= Phillip Hughes: Australian batsman dies, aged 25 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 27 November 2014|website=BBC News | accessdate= 27 November 2014}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Cricket}} *[[Cricket terminology]]

[[Image:Bafra.jpg|thumb|200px| Logo of BAFRA]]The '''British American Football Referees' Association''' ('''BAFRA''') is the organisational body for American Football Referees in Britain.<ref name="BAFRA_About_us">{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/index.htm |title=BAFRA - Information Page |website=BAFRA.info |publisher=www.bafra.info/info/index.htm |accessdate=18 November 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kentsport.org/american_football.asp |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402215639/http://kentsport.org/american_football.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 April 2016 |title=American Football - What's It All About |website=Kent Spoty |accessdate=18 November 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/american-football/news/12040/8955986/nfl-try-your-hand-at-being-an-american-football-official-in-british-league |title=NFL: Try your hand at being an American Football official in British League |date=4 October 2013 |website=skysports.com |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=2 December 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012221922/http://www1.skysports.com/american-football/news/12040/8955986/nfl-try-your-hand-at-being-an-american-football-official-in-british-league |archive-date=12 October 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> BAFRA is affiliated to the [[British American Football Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britishamericanfootball.org/referee/getting-started-in-refereeing#.VGu3YmfYL-k |title=Getting Started in Refereeing |website=British American Football |accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref>
BAFRA was established in 1984 and provides game officials for American Football games played in the British Leagues.<ref name="BAFRA_About_us" /> BAFRA officials are eligible to officiate in [[International Federation of American Football]] fixtures if selected to do so and in recent years BAFRA has provided personnel for the [[chain crew]]s at [[NFL International Series]] games played at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britishamericanfootball.org/news/nfl-from-the-sideline#.VH3ZQ8nva3F |title= NFL: From the Sideline |date=29 September 2014 |website=britishamericanfootball.org |accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref> For information on becoming an American Football Referee in Britain please see http://www.bafra.info/info/howtojoin.php
[[File:Referee Crew Wikipedia.jpg|thumb|right|A typical BAFRA crew at [[South Leeds Stadium]]]]
==Association Governance== There 8 directors of BAFRA and several working committees are convened during the year as required.<ref name="BAFRA_moa">{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/handbook/const/moa_revised.pdf |title=MEMORANDUM OF ASSOCIATION OF THE BRITISH AMERICAN FOOTBALL REFEREES ASSOCIATION LIMITED |date=31 March 2012 |accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref> The association has five stated objectives:<ref name="BAFRA_moa" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/handbook/const/aoa_final.pdf |title=ARTICLES OF ASSOCIATION OF THE BRITISH AMERICAN FOOTBALL REFEREES ASSOCIATION LIMITED |accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref> # To improve the standard of officiating by training and examination, and by any other means # To enable all American football games in Britain to have neutral officials # To promote and uphold the status of officials both collectively and individually # To co-operate and to cultivate good relations with all bodies concerned with American football, for the betterment of the game # To take such action or make such representation as an Association, or in conjunction with others as may be considered desirable, in the interests of American football in Britain in general or for the benefit of officials and officiating in particular
==Training== An annual convention is held (typically in March or April), during which a number of training videos and breakout sessions are conducted, together with the [[Annual General Meeting]].<ref>{{cite web|title=BAFRA Newsflash Issue: 08/10|url=http://www.bafra.info/newsflash/2010/201008.htm|publisher=BAFRA|accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> A guest speaker is invited to participate—to mark the association's 25th anniversary in 2009, the guest speaker was Greg Gautreaux, the field judge at [[Super Bowl XLIII#Officials|Super Bowl XLIII]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bafa.org.uk/artman2/publish/bafra/Greg_Gautreaux_guest_of_honour_at_BAFRA_shtml | title=Super Bowl official to mark BAFRA's silver jubilee | publisher=[[British American Football Association]] | date=26 February 2009 | accessdate=19 May 2010 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>. Individuals wishing to join BAFRA are taken through their theory training by an experienced official who will also act as their on-field mentor once they have passed a competency exam that allows them to officiate. <ref>http://www.bafra.info/info/handbook/training.php</ref>
==The John Slavin Trophy== John Slavin was a long-serving BAFRA official and also a director of the association, who died in October 2005. In his memory BAFRA dedicated an annual award to be made to any UK team that shows commitment to improving the game experience for players and fans, as well as officials. The criteria for the award is decided at the start of each season by the rules committee to reflect varying aspects of game management that would benefit from improvement.<ref name="Ips_Cards_Ref1">{{cite web |url=http://www.ipswichcardinals.co.uk/#/cardinals-win-awards/4586476280 |title=Cardinals win BAFRA Awards |date=15 September 2014 |website=www.ipswichcardinals.co.uk |accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="Camb_Cats_Ref1">{{cite web |url=http://www.cambridgeshirecats.com/senior/directions.htm |title=Cambrideshire Cats American Football Club |website=www.cambridgeshirecats.com |accessdate=2 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427064524/http://www.cambridgeshirecats.com/senior/directions.htm |archivedate=27 April 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="BAFRA_jst">{{cite web|url=http://www.bafra.info/info/jst/ |title=The John Slavin Trophy |publisher=BAFRA |accessdate=18 Nov 2014}}</ref>
'''Previous National winners of the trophy''' * 2018 - Norwich Devilsls<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/jst/index.php |title=John Slavin Trophy |access-date=5 September 2018}}</ref> * 2017 - Ipswich Cardinals<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/jst/index.php |title=John Slavin Trophy |access-date=26 August 2018}}</ref> * 2016 - Berkshire Renegades<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/jst/index.php |title=John Slavin Trophy |access-date=26 August 2018}}</ref> * 2015 - Ipswich Cardinals<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2015/BAFANL2015.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 201 5 BAFANL Season |access-date=27 November 2015 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2014 - [[Ipswich Cardinals]]<ref name="Ips_Cards_Ref1" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2014/BAFANL2014.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2014 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2013 - [[DC Presidents]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2013/BAFANL2013.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2013 BAFANL Season |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2012 - Cambridgeshire Cats<ref name="Camb_Cats_Ref1" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2012/BAFANL2012.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2012 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2011 - [[Colchester Gladiators]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2011/BAFANL2011.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2011 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2010 - [[Bedfordshire Blue Raiders]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2010/Results2010.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2010 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2009 - Edinburgh Wolves<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2009/200906JSA.htm |title=John Slavin Award 2009 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2008 - [[Oxford Saints]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2008/200801.htm |title=John Slavin Award 2008 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2007 - [[Edinburgh Wolves]]<ref name="BAFRA_jst" /> * 2006 - [[Cambridgeshire Cats]]<ref name="Camb_Cats_Ref1" /><ref name="BAFRA_jst" />
'''Previous University winners of the trophy''' * 2017-18 - Southampton Stags<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/jst/index.php |title=John Slavin Trophy |access-date=26 August 2018}}</ref> * 2016-17 - Cambridge Pythons<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/jst/index.php |title=John Slavin Trophy |access-date=26 August 2018}}</ref> * 2015-16 - Southampton Stags<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/jst/index.php |title=John Slavin Trophy |access-date=26 August 2018}}</ref> * 2014-15 - ARU Rhinos<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2015/BUCS2015.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2014-15 BUCS Season |access-date=27 November 2015 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2013-14 - Southampton Stags<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2014/BUCS2014.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2013-14 BUCS Season |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2012-13 - UEA Pirates<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2013/BUCS2013.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2012-13 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2011-12 - Southampton Stags<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2012/Universities201112.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2011-12 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2010-11 - [[University of East Anglia|UEA Pirates]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/info/press/2011/Universities201011.pdf |title=John Slavin Award 2010-11 |accessdate=2 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2008-09 - [[Anglia Ruskin University|Anglia Ruskin Phantoms]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/neutralzone/2009/nz200902.pdf |title=NEUTRAL ZONE - BAFRA's newsletter for clubs and teams |accessdate=4 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2007-08 - [[University of Southampton|Southampton Stags]]<ref name="BAFRA_jst" /> * 2006-07 - [[University of Surrey|Surrey Stingers]]<ref name="BAFRA_jst" />
==Weekly newsletter== Within its website BAFRA publishes an open weekly online newsletter called ''Newsflash'' that includes items of interest, notices of appointment, game reports, disciplinary decisions and any rule changes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dblcoverage.com/bafa-reject-dreadnoughts-appeal/ |title=BAFA reject Dreadnoughts appeal |last1=Snee |first1=Tom |date=10 October 2014 |website=dblcoverage.com |publisher=Double Coverage |accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafra.info/newsflash/index_public.php |title=BAFRA Newsflash |accessdate=4 December 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>. Whilst the purpose of Newsflash is primarily to inform BAFRA members, it is made available to the general public via the BAFRA website.

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | image = dolphin2.jpg | image_size = 220px | stadium_name = Dolphin Oval | location = [[Kippa-Ring, Queensland]] | coordinates = {{coord|27|13|8|S|153|5|50|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = Late-1970s | opened = May 1979 | owner = [[Redcliffe Dolphins]] | operator = Redcliffe Dolphins | surface = Grass | tenants = [[Redcliffe Dolphins]] ([[Queensland Cup]])
[[Peninsula Power Football Club|Peninsula Power]] ([[FFA Cup]]) | seating_capacity = 15,000 }} '''Dolphin Oval''', based on the corner of Ashmole and Klingner Roads in [[Kippa-Ring, Queensland|Kippa-Ring]], north of [[Brisbane]], is the home ground for the [[Redcliffe Dolphins]] [[rugby league]] football club, who play in the [[Queensland Cup|Queensland Intrust Super Cup]]. The ground regularly hosts pre-season [[National Rugby League|NRL]] trials, and hosted the 2001, 2002 and 2003 Queensland Cup Grand Finals. ==History== The creation of the Dolphin Oval began when the [[City of Redcliffe|Redcliffe City Council]] made re-claimed land available for sporting fields in the 1970s. The [[Redcliffe Dolphins]], who at the time were based at the Redcliffe Showgrounds, showed immediate interest and applied for the maximum area available. Redcliffe City Council engineer Kevin Tibbets took to the construction of the ground with the utmost enthusiasm, with the football club even hosting a trip interstate for him to study playing arenas in New South Wales. The transition from the Redcliffe Showgrounds to Dolphin Oval presented some major problems. Due to the isolation of the area at the time of construction, normal services were not readily available and therefore had to be brought in. Due to the gravity flow to Klingner Road, expensive sewerage pumps had to be brought in, power for the floodlights had to go underground to the main oval and the run-through tunnel was [[transhipped]] from Western Australia at a cost of $9,000, which was still cheaper than buying one from the Eastern states. The lighting at the showgrounds was far superior, but the Redcliffe Rugby League Old Boys, led by Neil Okamura, contributed a $5,000 loan, which was later turned into a grant, for suitable floodlighting. They also constructed a perimeter playing fence around the main oval at a cost of $2,780. In return, the football club provided the Old Boys with a solid can-booth at the northern end of the complex and were granted the rights to sell liquor on a commission basis. The pressure to build a licensed club at Dolphin Oval was met with a great deal of caution, especially when the existing club at the Showgrounds was still profitable. But within 12 months after the sod-turning ceremony, the new clubhouse was opened by the Mayor of Redcliffe, Ald. Alf Charlish. With the help of the Federal Member for Petrie, [[Dean Wells (politician)|Dean Wells]], and his Government's contribution through their C.E.P. Funding, along with the football club's own financial arrangements with the [[Commonwealth Bank]], the move was made possible. However the heavily publicised and enforced "Don't Drink and Drive" policy by the Government struck the thriving bar trade, and, according to ''From Shellgrit to Dolphins'', a book on the History of the Redcliffe Dolphins, says: ''"Suffice to say the club only barely kept its doors open and its creditors at bay until the advent of poker machines in 1992, but proudly was able to meet its financial commitments"'' In January 1979, the committee proposed to name the complex the Don McLennan Oval, but Mr McLennan requested that it be called Dolphin Oval. Fittingly, the first game at Dolphin Oval was between [[Redcliffe Dolphins|Redcliffe]] and [[Norths Devils|Norths]], the club that originally proposed Redcliffe's admission into the BRL. The original lease was acquired to 1998 and later extended to 2008, before the Redcliffe Dolphins bought the land. ==Redevelopment and renaming== The ground was redeveloped between 2015 and 2018 following announcement of the programme in 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/questnews/moreton/redcliffe-dolphins-has-revealed-plans-for-a-12-million-stadium-at-dolphin-oval/story-fni9r1i7-1226907637419 |title=Redcliffe Dolphins has revealed plans for a $12 million stadium at Dolphin Oval |date=6 May 2014 |work=Courier Mail |accessdate=6 February 2018}} After securing funding from [[Moreton Bay Region|Moreton Bay Regional Council]] and the [[Government of Australia|Federal Government funding]] phase 1 of the redeveloped ground, now called Dolphin Stadium was opened.{{cite web |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/questnews/moreton/new-redcliffe-dolphins-rugby-league-stadium-takes-shape-at-redcliffe/news-story/5989b6fccb7a068ee37fe3ab8165991f?nk=c0e4c77c696a080799051b273655d281-1517932856 |title=New Redcliffe Dolphins rugby league stadium takes shape at Redcliffe |work=Courier Mail |date=16 May 2016 |accessdate=6 February 2018}} The second phase of work completed in February 2018.{{cite web |url=http://redcliffedolphins.com.au/dolphin-stadium/ |title=Dolphin Stadium |publisher=Redcliffe Dolphins |accessdate=6 February 2018}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == Sources == * McLennan, Don, ''From Shellgrit to Dolphins: A History of the Redcliffe District Rugby League Football Club'', 1995, Peninsula Printers. ==External links== * {{Austadiums|191}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130219025506/http://www.rleague.com/db/venue/dolphin_oval/ Dolphin Oval at Rleague.com] [[Category:Sports venues in Brisbane]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Redcliffe Dolphins]] [[Category:1979 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1979]]

{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = JSC ZAZ Stadium | nickname = Stadion Avto ZAZ | image = Zaporizhia ZAZ Stadium 2.jpg | location = [[Zaporizhia]], [[Ukraine]] | coordinates = {{coord|47|48|4.54|N|35|11|35.98|E|region:UA|display=inline}} | broke_ground = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[ZAZ]], [[Zaporizhia]] | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[FC Torpedo Zaporizhia]] (1982-2001)
[[FC Metalurh Zaporizhia]] (2001-2006) | seating_capacity = 15,000 ([[football (soccer)|football]]) | dimensions = ? }} '''JSC ZAZ Stadium''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Zaporizhia]], [[Ukraine]] that belongs to the Zaporizhia Car-manufacturing Plant ([[ZAZ]]). The stadium's capacity is 15,000 people. The stadium is located right next to the factory, just across a railroad. It is located in the southern part of the city and urban residential area. Near the stadium flows a small river Mokra-Moskovka which is a left tributary of [[Dnieper]]. Near the stadium is located a train station Zaporizhia-1, while the stadium itself is about mile away down the Kosmichna vulytsia (local street) from the main highway {{Highway M (Ukraine)|18}} {{European route E|105}}. Originally the stadium was a home to the factory team [[FC Torpedo Zaporizhia]] that existed in 1982-2002. In 2001-2006 the stadium was the home of [[FC Metalurh Zaporizhia]] as the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Top League]] suspended Metaurh's home stadium in 2001 due to safety concerns. In July 2006, the team returned to its renovated [[Slavutych Arena]]. Here on 7 May 2002 during the Ukrainian Top League game Metalurh - Dynamo, [[Valeriy Lobanovsky]] received a heart attack, after which five days later he died in one of the Zaporizhia city clinics. ==References== {{reflist}} {{FC Metalurh Zaporizhia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jsc Zaz Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in Ukraine]] [[Category:Sport in Zaporizhia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Zaporizhia]] [[Category:FC Metalurh Zaporizhya]] [[Category:ZAZ]] [[Category:FC Torpedo Zaporizhya]] [[Category:Sports venues in Zaporizhia Oblast]] {{Ukraine-sports-venue-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{good article}} {{Infobox person | name = John Hemmingham | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = John Hemmingham | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1963|02|26}}<ref name=pie>{{cite web|url=http://englandband.pukkapies.co.uk/the-team/john-hemmingham |title=John Hemmingham |publisher=Pukka Pies |date= |accessdate=6 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609041330/http://englandband.pukkapies.co.uk/the-team/john-hemmingham |archivedate= 9 June 2013 |df= }}</ref> | birth_place = [[Sheffield]], England<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrybookshop.co.uk/cgi-bin/search.pl?searchtype=author&searchtext=Hemmingham+John |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130504224744/http://www.countrybookshop.co.uk/cgi-bin/search.pl?searchtype=author&searchtext=Hemmingham+John |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 May 2013 |title=Hemmingham, John |publisher=Country Book Shop |date= |accessdate=6 April 2013 }}</ref> | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | other_names = "Hema"<ref name=pie /> | known_for = Leader of the [[Pukka Pies England Band]] | occupation = Commercial manager }} '''John Hemmingham''' (born 26 February 1963) is an association football supporter and football administrator from [[Sheffield]], England. He is best known as the leader and trumpet player of the [[Pukka Pies England Band]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18431515 |title=Euro 2012: England band 'has bulldog spirit' |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=13 June 2012 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> Hemmingham first started playing music at football in 1993 with [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] fans. In 1996, he was invited to play at [[England national football team]] matches. He has since played at other sporting events including the [[Olympics]] and [[boxing]] matches.
Hemmingham also works in football administration. He started in 2001 as the chief executive of [[Wednesdayite|The Owls Trust]] until a dispute with the Sheffield Wednesday chairman caused him to resign in 2004. Hemmingham then went on to work at other football clubs, including [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] and [[Mansfield Town F.C.|Mansfield Town]] before taking a position at Sheffield Wednesday after his relations improved with them. He also married in 2007.
== Band ==
===Sheffield Wednesday=== Hemmingham started playing music at football matches in 1993 when he took a bugle to a Sheffield Wednesday match away at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]'s [[Goodison Park]] and played the fanfare to [[Aida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://englandfans.thefa.com/ef/pages/news.aspx?id=45636dd8-a94b-444a-97a3-c6bee0e4d081 |title=Band Aid |publisher=The Football Association |date=15 October 2010 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> The action was noticed by local newspapers and after a phone call to Hemmingham from Sheffield Wednesday manager, [[Trevor Francis]],<ref name=fl /> Sheffield Wednesday then hired Hemmingham and group of Sheffield Wednesday supporters to form an official club band which became known as the "''Kop Band''".<ref>{{cite web|author=Duleep Allirajah |url=http://www.spiked-online.com/Articles/00000002D3E3.htm |title=The Sheffield Wednesday Kop Band banned |publisher=Spiked Online |date=31 January 2002 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> Although the band became popular, Hemmingham and the Kop Band have been banned from [[Steel City derby]] rivals [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]'s stadium, [[Bramall Lane]] a number of times. In 2002, they were banned from Bramall Lane because Sheffield United were concerned that playing music might lead to "unsafe crowd movement" and "unacceptable structural movement" by Sheffield United's safety officer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3A+BRASSED+OFF+BAND.-a082280522 |title=Brassed off Band. |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]'' (The Free Library) |date= |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> In 2007, they were also banned because it was claimed by Sheffield United officials that playing music might cause structural damage to the stands to which, Hemmingham led criticism of it calling the ban "laughable".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/120431/.html |title=All the top football stories |work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |date=3 August 2007 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
===England=== In 1996, Hemmingham, along with the Kop Band, were invited by the head of [[The Football Association]], [[David Davies (football administrator)|David Davies]] to form a supporters band for the England national team in time for [[UEFA Euro 96]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Heard |first=Chris |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/3579800.stm |title=Great Escape soccer fans' tribute |publisher=BBC News |date=19 August 2004 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> Hemmingham accepted and the Kop Band became known as the ''England Supporters Band''. Since then, Hemmingham claims he has not missed an England game.<ref name=stags>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7631675.stm |title=Stags chief settling into role |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=23 September 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> As well as being viewed as the leader of the band, Hemmingham is also the managing director of them.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/research/news/?itemno=10143 |title=Drum rhythm on song for World Cup success |publisher=[[Durham University]] |date=7 June 2010 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
After being offered a recording deal by [[Virgin Group]] chairman, [[Richard Branson]],<ref name=peak /> Hemmingham and the band released ''[[The Great Escape (film)|The Great Escape]]'' theme tune as singles for the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]] and [[UEFA Euro 2000]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chartstats.com/artistinfo.php?id=8534 |title=ChartArchive – England Supporters' Band |publisher=Chart Stats |date=30 December 2012 |accessdate=4 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130119064241/http://www.chartstats.com/artistinfo.php?id=8534 |archivedate=19 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The England Supporters band then started received backing from commercial sponsors. In 2002, the band was sponsored by British newspaper, ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' who paid for the band to fly to Japan for the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/150011/.html |title=Band of the Rising Sun |work=The Sun |date=3 August 2007 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> In 2006, the band were sponsored by [[Leicester]]-based company [[Pukka Pies]], becoming known as the Pukka Pies England Band.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/leicester/content/articles/2006/05/11/pukka_worldcup_feature.shtml |title=Footballs' pukka band! |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
In 2010 publishers, Peakpublish announced they had signed a deal with Hemmingham for him to write two books about the formation of the ''England Supporters Band'' and his experiences with them. The books were called ''The Story of the England Supporters' Band''<ref name=peak>{{cite web|url=http://www.peakpublish.com/jhemmingham/band/ |title=The Story of the England Supporters' Band by John Hemmingham acquired by Peakpublish |publisher=Peakpublish |date= |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> and ''Playing for England''.<ref>{{cite book | first = John | last = Hemmingham | title = Playing for England| publisher = Peakpublic | location = | year = 2010| isbn = 1907219102 | page = }}</ref>
===Other sports=== Hemmingham has also led the ''England Band'' to other sporting events. In 2008, Hemmingham took the band to Beijing, China during the [[Beijing 2008]] Summer Olympics to support [[Great Britain at the Olympics|Team GB]]<ref name=fl>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/20080814/owls-band-marches-on-olympics_2293322_1365767 |title=Owls band marches on Olympics |publisher=[[The Football League]] |date=14 August 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> however they were not permitted to enter the [[Beijing National Stadium]] with their instruments and instead played on the streets of Beijing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/south_yorkshire/7571177.stm |title=Olympic ban a sour note with band |publisher=BBC News |date=19 August 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> In 2012, during the [[London 2012]] [[Summer Olympics]] it was announced that the ''England Band'' would be supporting both the [[Great Britain men's national field hockey team]] and the [[Great Britain women's national field hockey team]] during their matches at the Olympics.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/Band-drumming-support-Team-GB/story-16589653-detail/story.html |title=Band drumming up support for Team GB |publisher=''This is Leicestershire'' |date=25 July 2012 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> Hemmingham has also taken the band to [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], United States as well as the [[City of Manchester Stadium]] to support [[Manchester]] [[boxing|boxer]], [[Ricky Hatton]]. They have also attended [[Rugby sevens]] matches to support the [[England national rugby sevens team|England national team]].<ref name=fl />
== Football administration == Hemmingham first started in football administration as the chief executive of an independent supporters group called The Owls Trust, which he helped establish, in 2001.<ref name=chad /> The Owls Trust was disliked by many Sheffield Wednesday fans and by Sheffield Wednesday chairman [[Dave Allen (football chairman)|Dave Allen]] as it was perceived that it was a vehicle leading towards a takeover by [[Ken Bates]], then chairman of Sheffield Wednesday's rivals [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], as The Owls Trust controlled a large amount of shares and Hemmingham had publicly stated support for Bates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_wed/3696187.stm |title=Owls ambition drives Bates |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 May 2004 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
After an attempted [[boardroom coup]] by The Owls Trust to remove Allen from the chairmanship in an [[extraordinary general meeting]] in October 2004,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_wed/3763914.stm |title=Trust seek to oust Owls chairman |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 October 2004 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> in 2005, The Owls Trust were evicted from their offices at [[Hillsborough Stadium]], Hemmingham was banned from executive areas of the stadium<ref>{{cite web|author=Amy Lawrence |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2004/nov/07/newsstory.sport4 |title=The game that ate itself |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=7 November 2004 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> and The Kop Band was asked to reduce its numbers by Allen. Hemmingham's ban was then later extended to a full stadium ban from Hillsborough.<ref name=ban>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/latestnews/20090109/owls-banned-band-man-is-back_2293301_1512897 |title=Owls' banned band man is back! |publisher=The Football League |date= |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> As a result of this, after securing an area for matchday parking, Hemmingham resigned to take a full-time position at Bates' Leeds United as head of customer services and membership.<ref name=chad>{{cite web|author=Thursday 2|url=http://www.chad.co.uk/sport/football/mansfield-town-fc/new-stags-chief-to-call-the-tune-1-704603 |title=New Stags chief to call the tune |publisher=''Mansfield and Ashfield Chad'' |date=28 August 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> This led to Hemmingham receiving death threats from Sheffield Wednesday fans.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/other-clubs/owls-fan-s-switch-sparks-death-threats-1-2557215 |title=Owls fan's switch sparks death threats |publisher=''Yorkshire Post'' |date=21 March 2005 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
In January 2008, Hemmingham left Leeds United and in August, he was appointed as the chief executive of [[Non-League football|non-league]] side, Mansfield Town<ref name=stags /> where he oversaw the expansion of the capacity of their [[Field Mill]] stadium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Stags-building-future-Field/story-12236452-detail/story.html |title=Mansfield building ambitious plans for future |publisher=''This is Nottingham'' |date=11 October 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> However, in January 2009, he left his position after three months.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/mansfield_town/7809627.stm |title=Holdsworth assembles Stags staff |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 January 2009 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> Also in January, his relations with Sheffield Wednesday improved after Allen was no longer chairman and the new directors at the club, [[Lee Strafford]] and Nick Parker elected to remove Hemmingham's ban from Hillsborough.<ref name=ban /> In 2011, Hemmingham rejoined Sheffield Wednesday as the Commercial Manager of [[Sheffield Wednesday Ladies]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://files.pitchero.com/clubs/8596/Vs%20Liverpool%20Feds%20-%20HG8.pdf |title=Sheffield Wednesday Women's FC vs. Liverpool Feds Ladies FC |publisher=Sheffield Wednesday Women matchday programme |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
== Personal life == Hemmingham has been married since 2007.<ref>{{cite web|first=Adam|last=Cusick|url=http://www.quaysnews.net/Playing_for_England-2564.html|title=Playing for England|publisher=Quays News|date=16 February 2012|accessdate=6 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703171243/http://www.quaysnews.net/Playing_for_England-2564.html|archivedate=3 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|33em}}

page.title: List of people who have run across Australia

revision.text:
{{about|people who have run, and are currently running, across or around Australia|a list of people who have walked across Australia|List of people who have walked across Australia }} {{refimprove|date=May 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2011}} [[File:LocationAU.svg|thumb|Location of Australia]] [[File:Australian Extremities.png|thumb|Map depicting the geographical extremes of Australia, and the cities at each point of the compass.]]
People who choose to run across [[Australia]] can choose to run from either of the [[Extreme points of Australia|geographical extremes]] of the continent, or from directly opposed cities on opposite shores. The western-most geographical extreme of Australia is [[Steep Point, Western Australia|Steep Point]], whereas the eastern-most extreme is [[Cape Byron]]. Similarly, the northern-most geographical extreme is [[Cape York Peninsula]], and the southern-most is the [[South East Cape]]. The distance between the east and west [[as the crow flies]] is {{convert|4030|km|mi|abbr=on}}, or {{convert|3685|km|mi|abbr=on}} from north to south†. The western-most capital city in Australia is [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], and the eastern-most capital city is [[Brisbane, Queensland|Brisbane]]. The northern-most city is [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], and the southern to the southern-most city is [[Hobart]].
Runners who choose to [[Circumambulation|circumambulate]] Australia can follow the [[National Highway (Australia)|National Highway]] for large sections of their journey. Distances involved are in the vicinity of {{convert|14300|km|mi|abbr=on}}<ref name="circum1">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Deborah DeWilliam's Town Itinerary|url=http://www.walkaroundoz.org.au/townitinerary.pdf|date=16 June 2004|accessdate=4 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219053718/http://walkaroundoz.org.au/townitinerary.pdf|archivedate=19 February 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> depending on the route taken.
<small>''†Distance calculated utilising the resources of [http://www.ga.gov.au/map/names/distance.jsp Geoscience Australia].''</small>
==Completed journeys== The names of the individuals who have run across Australia have been listed below in chronological order. Sources for data contained within this table have been listed within the body of the article, or where not readily available, directly from the individual concerned.
{{inc-sport}}

|- | James Brooman|| {{Flag|UK}} || March 2015 || May 2015 || 81 days || Perth || Sydney |- | Jason P. Lester<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.batemansbaypost.com.au/story/4098196/lester-legs-it-to-clyde/?cs=229|title=‘You have a long way to go’: Jason’s epic run to the Clyde from Perth|last=O'CONNOR|first=KERRIE|date=2016-08-15|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref>|| {{USA}} || March 2016 || August 2016 || 118 days || Scarborough Beach || Batemans Bay |- |Greg Brown |{{AUS}} |2 April 2016 |22 June 2016 |82 days |South East Cape, Tasmania |Cape York, Queensland |- |Andre Jones |{{AUS}} |10 March 2017 |13 June 2017 |93 days |[[Melbourne]] |Darwin |- |Richard Bowles |UK |1 June 2012 |1 September |457 days |Healsville, VIC |Cooktown, QLD |}
===George Perdon=== George Perdon ran across Australia during the 1973 Trans-Continental Run, completing the {{convert|4807|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} journey in 47 days, 1 hour and 54 minutes. He averaged {{convert|100|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} per day, and set records for {{convert|1000|mi|km}}, {{convert|1500|mi|km}}, {{convert|2000|mi|km}} and {{convert|2600|mi|km}}.<ref name="george">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=George Perdon|url=http://www.aura.asn.au/GeorgePerdon.html|date=|accessdate=21 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719165432/http://www.aura.asn.au/GeorgePerdon.html|archivedate=19 July 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Perdon became a household name in 1973 when competing in the 1973 Trans Australia race and racing his rival - Tony Rafferty. Perdon was unable to get time off work at the appropriate time and missed the official start, giving Rafferty one week's head start before heading off from Fremantle. Perdon was to end up beating Rafferty into Sydney by a day. They took slightly different routes during the run, causing the run to generate front-page headlines for a majority of the journey.<ref name="george"/>
Perdon died on 29 June 1993.<ref name="george"/>
===Tony Rafferty=== In 1972, Tony Rafferty became the first man to run from Melbourne to Sydney, pioneering ultra-distance running in Australia. He was also the first man to run from Perth to Adelaide, Adelaide to Brisbane, Melbourne to Brisbane and Sydney to Brisbane. In 1978, he became the first man to run from Melbourne to Sydney and return.<ref name = "rafferty4">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Speaker Tony Rafferty|url=http://www.icmi.com.au/Speaker/Sports/Tony_Rafferty/Biography|date=|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref> In August to October 1973 Tony became the first person to run from [[Fremantle]] to the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], and in the process became the first person to run across the [[Nullarbor Plain]].<ref name="rafferty1">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Tony Rafferty|url=http://www.aura.asn.au/TonyRafferty.html|date=|accessdate=21 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219222126/http://www.aura.asn.au//TonyRafferty.html|archivedate=19 February 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He completed the run in 74 days.<ref name = "rafferty3">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=A History of the Marathon Race — 490 B.C. to 1975|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JSH/JSH1976/JSH0302/jsh0302d.pdf|date=|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref>
Tony has received many commendations for his achievements. Most notably, he was a [[Olympic Flame|Torch Bearer]] for the [[Sydney 2000 Olympics|Sydney 2000 Olympic Games]], and the recipient of the Medal of the [[Order of Australia]] (OAM) in 2002 for services to Ultramarathon Running and the promotion of Community Fitness.<ref name="rafferty1"/>
===Ron Grant=== {{main article|Ron Grant (runner)}} In 1983, Ron Grant ran {{convert|13383|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} around Australia in 217 days. Ron completed the run in an anticlockwise direction. Starting in [[Brisbane]], he then proceeded to [[Townsville]], [[Mt Isa]], [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Adelaide]], [[Melbourne]], [[Sydney]], then back to Brisbane. He maintained an overall daily average of {{convert|61.67|km|mi|2|abbr=on}}, and was the first person to do it solo. Soon after this achievement, he was awarded the Queensland Sportsman of the year Award in 1983, Queenslander of the Year in 1984, and the [[Order of Australia]] in 1984.<ref name = "grant1">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Ron Grant|url=http://austultrahistory.wikispaces.com/Ron+Grant|date=|accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref><ref name = "grant2">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=World Harmony Run: 75 Ron Grant|url=http://www.worldharmonyrun.org/au/torch_bearer/gallery/75_ron_grant|date=|accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref>
===Sarah Covington Fulcher=== The first woman to run across Australia, at age 24, from North Carolina, USA, running {{convert|2727|mi|km}} east to west from Bondi Beach, NSW to the western suburbs of Perth, Western Australia, 22 Sep to 26 Dec 1986.<ref>Russell, A. (1988). The Guinness Book of Records with Australian Supplement. Enfield, England: Guinness Books, pp. 350-351</ref> Fulcher describes her journey through remote areas in an interview with Bryant Gumbel on NBC's [http://www.nbcuniversalarchives.com/nbcuni/searchResults.do?search.type=intermediate&search.withinKeywords=&search.withinResults=&search.keywords=Sarah%20Fulcher&filter= ''Today Show'']. "Sarah Fulcher set her incredible record one marathon at a time. It was an unparalleled feat that will take a heck of a commitment to beat. During her record run, Fulcher averaged 10 minutes per mile."<ref>Kevles, B. (1989, March). The longest run ever. Women's Sports and Fitness Magazine, 11(2), 67</ref> "This would also make her the youngest person (at that time) to make any transcontinental run."<ref>[http://www.crazyfeatherspublishing.com/ Morris, D (2011). Sarah's Long Run: Highlights from Sarah Covington Fulcher's World's Record Longest Run. Jamestown, North Carolina: Crazy Feathers Publishing, p. 14] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313091332/http://www.crazyfeatherspublishing.com/ |date=13 March 2012 }}</ref>
Sarah also set the Guinness world record for longest continuous solo run with a distance of {{convert|11134|mi|km}} in 438 days.<ref>Matthews, P. (1989). The Guinness Book of Records 1990. Enfield, England: Guinness Books, pp. 298-299.</ref> "Sarah Fulcher, an attractive, {{Sic|?|hide=y|brightly|-}}smiling, 25-year-old native of Winston Salem, N. C., jogged through Sequin this week on her way back to Laguna Hills, Calif., near Los Angeles, from where she began her 11,000 mile run...the world's longest, continuous solo run in history.<ref>Gossett, G. (5 June 1988). It's a very big run for a slip of a girl. Sequin-Gazette-Enterprise, p. 1A</ref> "Fulcher has been recognized by untold news organizations and government organizations including the Connecticut General Assembly Permanent Committee on the Status of Women's (CTPCSW) publication ''Selected Highlights of Women's History'' (page 38) and the United States Congressional Record in a "Salute to Sarah Covington Fulcher".<ref>Lowery, B. (15 May 1989). Salute to Sarah Covington Fulcher. United States of America Congressional Record Proceedings and Debates of the 101st Congress. First Session (135) 61.</ref>
===Robert Garside=== {{main article|Robert Garside}} Robert Garside is a British runner who ran through 29 countries on six different continents covering more than {{convert|48000|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} and covering a period of 2,062 days.<ref name = "garside1">{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Around the world in 2040 days|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2007/03/27/1174761428006.html|date=27 March 2007|accessdate=4 April 2011|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> He started and finished in [[New Delhi]] on 20 October 1997, and finished on 13 June 2003.<ref name = "garside3">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Earliest Run around the World|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/mediazone/pdfs/news/070327_Earliest_Run_around_the_World.pdf|date=27 March 2007|accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref> He had completed his Australian leg of the run by April 2000.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JWRWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MPIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6834,5291732&dq=robert+garside+australia&hl=en|first=Steven|last=Gutman|title=Around the World|date=6 April 2000|accessdate=13 June 2011|work=The Spokesman-Review}}</ref>
===Serge Girard=== {{main article|Serge Girard}} Serge Girard ran from [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] to [[Sydney]] in 1999, covering a distance of {{convert|3755|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} in 46 days, 23 hours, 12 min and setting a world record in the process. The world record remained intact until beaten by Achim Heukemes in 2005.<ref name="serge1">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Trans Australia|url=http://www.sergegirard.com/old/trans-australia/index.en.html|date=|accessdate=21 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023174957/http://www.sergegirard.com/old/trans-australia/index.en.html|archivedate=23 October 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name = "serge2">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Serge Girard Attempting Trans-Australia record|url=http://www.coolrunning.com.au/ultra/1999028.shtml|date=6 September 1999|accessdate=21 May 2011}}</ref>
===Jesper Olsen=== {{main article|Jesper Olsen (runner)}} Jesper Olsen is a Danish marathon runner who ran across Australia as part of his first journey around the world.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/27/sports/27iht-RUN.html|title=Global run tries soles of one man|work=New York Times|first=Ira|last=Berkow|date=27 October 2005|accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> He departed from [[Sydney]] on 31 October 2004, and arrived in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] on 11 February 2005.<ref name = "olsen1">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Route Info - Part 4 - Australia|url=http://www1.worldrun.org/route-part4.shtml|date=|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref><ref name = "olsen2">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Progress map|url=http://www1.worldrun.org/progresmap.shtml|date=|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="olsen3">{{cite web|last= |first= |title=Jesper Olsen Completes Australian Leg of World Run |url=http://au.srichinmoyraces.org/resources/Jesper%20Olsen |date=7 September 2009 |accessdate=28 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728050244/http://au.srichinmoyraces.org/resources/Jesper%20Olsen |archivedate=28 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> He completed the journey in 104 days, before proceeding onto [[Los Angeles]] to complete the American leg of his run around the world.
===Achim Heukemes=== Achim Heukemes (born 1951 in [[Wuppertal]], Germany) is an [[ultramarathon]] runner known for his 4,568-kilometre run through [[Australia]]. He started from [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]] on 2 April 2005 and finished in [[Sydney]] 43 days, 13 hours and 8 minutes later. By this feat, he beat the previous world record of [[Serge Girard]] from 1999.<ref name = "achim1">{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Achim Down Under (2005)|url=http://www.heukemes.net/|date=|accessdate=28 May 2011}}</ref>
===Remi Camus=== {{unreferenced section|date=July 2014}} [[:fr:Rémi_Camus|Rémi Camus]] ran across [[Australia]], Capital to Capital, Melbourne to the Top End, [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]]. He covered his journey in 100 days at an average of {{convert|54|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} per day ( more than {{convert|5300|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}). He completed his journey with no vehicle support, pulling a trailer of {{convert|45|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}}. He went to visit two Aboriginal Communities, Docker River located {{convert|182|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} west of [[Kata Tjuta]] and [[Mutitjulu]] located behind [[Uluṟu-Kata Tjuṯa National Park|Uluru]]. He recorded his journey with 2 video cameras. He also raised money for a charity<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.syndrome-lowe.org/project/remi-camus-en-australie/|title=Rémi Camus en Australie – ASL – Association française du Syndrome de Lowe|website=www.syndrome-lowe.org|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref>, [[:fr:Syndrome_de_Lowe|Syndrome of Lowe]], a genetic disease that affect mostly boys.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailymotion.com/video/xx5zzr|title=Sur les routes australiennes avec Rémi Camus - Vidéo dailymotion|date=2013-02-01|website=Dailymotion|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref>
===Cesar Guarin=== Cesar Guarin ran across Australia in 2011, as part of his [[Global Run: Alay sa Pilipino at sa Buong Mundo|Global Run]] for an advocacy to help Filipino children experiencing poverty. His run across Australia was the fifth leg of his Global run and has a total distance of {{convert|2053|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} from [[Melbourne]] to [[Brisbane]]. The Australian run hoped to raise $200,000 funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/240709/pinoyabroad/cesar-guarin-ends-australia-leg-of-global-run|title=Cesar Guarin ends Australia leg of global run | Pinoy Abroad | GMA News Online|publisher=Gmanetwork.com|date=6 December 2011|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://theglobalrun.org/australia_run.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114061615/http://theglobalrun.org/australia_run.html |archivedate=14 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Pat Farmer===
[[Pat Farmer]] established the fastest around Australia long run record of continuous running in 191 days and 10 minutes (around 6 months) over {{convert|14662.4|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} during his Centenary of Federation run. He set a new world {{convert|10000|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} record in 129 days, broke a long-standing Australian record of more than {{convert|13383|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} in 174 days. He set a total of ten international records including the Western Australia border to border run, the Brisbane to Darwin run, and the world record for the longest tropics run ({{convert|6307|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} in 83 days).<ref>[http://pandora.nla.gov.au/tep/10383]</ref>
===Deborah De Williams {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM}}=== [[Deborah De Williams]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM}} successfully walked around Australia in 2003-04, and set a world record for the longest walk by any woman in the process. On 25 October 2008, she began running from [[Hobart]] in an anti-clockwise direction to raise funds for the national breast Cancer Foundation. She made it to [[Darwin, Australia|Darwin]] before being injured, and was subsequently forced to withdraw from the run on 5 June 2009. On 27 March 2010, she restarted her run again from Hobart and successfully circumambulated the continent on 8 May 2011. In doing so, she set another world record for the longest run for a woman.<ref>{{cite book|last=Norris|first=Megan|title=Running Pink|year=2012|publisher=Five Mile Press|isbn=9781743006894}}</ref> In 2015 Deborah was awarded the Member of the Order of Australia in the Australia Day Honours for her service to the cancer community and ultra marathoning community and in doing so is officially recognised as the first woman to run around Australia.<ref>{{cite web|author=Governor-General|title=2015 Australia Day Awards|url=http://www.gg.gov.au/sites/default/files/files/honours/ad/ad2015/Media%20Notes%20-%20AM%20(A-L).pdf#page=25|website=www.gg.gov.au/|publisher=Governor-General of Australia|accessdate=26 January 2015}}</ref>
===Patrick Malandain=== Patrick Malandain (born 1960) ran across Australia from Sydney to Fremantle (Perth) during the 2013 Trans-Continental Run, completing the {{convert|3861|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}race in 38 days, 12 hours and 58 minutes. He ran average {{convert|100.177|km|mi|3|abbr=on}} per day. He breaks Achim Heukemes's record since 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://patrickmalandain-ultrarun.com|title=Patrick Malandain, coureur ultra | La victoire sur soi est la plus grande des victoires|publisher=Patrickmalandain-ultrarun.com|date=3 November 2013|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>{{Self-published inline|date=July 2014}}. It's the new world record.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}
===Janette Murray-Wakelin and Alan Murray=== Experienced ultra-marathoners Janette Murray Wakelin and Alan Murray successfully ran/walked around Australia in 2013. Taking only 366 days to complete the journey, the couple aged in their 60s ran no less than 1 marathon, {{convert|42.195|km|mi|3|abbr=on}} in any one day, and most days did much closer to {{convert|45|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}. They followed predominantly [[Highway 1 (Australia)|Highway 1]]. Janette Murray-Wakelin and Alan Murray promoted the raw food movement and demonstrated its function to sustain the human body in optimum performance. They only consumed raw plant matter to fuel their whole run.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://runningrawaroundaustralia.com|title=Cancer Survivor Janette Murray-Wakelin & partner Alan Murray Running Around Australia RunOz2013 - About RunRAW2013|publisher=Runningrawaroundaustralia.com|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>{{Self-published inline|date=July 2014}}
===Tony Mangan=== Tony Mangan ran across Australia south to north on his world run (in which he covered 50000 km in 4 Years from 2010 to 2014) Started on Australian mainland in Queenscliff, Melbourne on March 13th. Finish Australian mainland in Nightscliff Beach, Darwin (Nightscliff Pool) May 25th. Distance run on the mainland was 3777km in 69 road days. Average distance run per road day was 54.73km. 5 rest days taken. Average distance including rest days was 51km for the 74 days. This has been declared as a new Melbourne to Darwin Trans Australian record by Phil Essam former Australian ultra running vice president, historian, statistician and author. Hobart Airport to Burnie, Tasmania and including the mainland has also been declared a second Trans Australian record for Tasmania to Darwin. Total Australian distance run 4,064km
===Mark Allison=== Mark Allison is known as Run Geordie Run and as part of his charity money raising he completed the run across Australia in January 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tyne-25612473|title=BBC News - Run Geordie Run Mark Allison lands back in Newcastle}}</ref>
===James Brooman=== James Brooman ran from Cottesloe Beach, [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], to Bondi Beach, [[Sydney]]. The journey was solo and unsupported, with James pushing a buggy the entire distance. Beginning on March 11, 2015 he completed the journey of {{convert|2562|mi|km|0|abbr=on}} in a time of 81 days, 5 hours 55 minutes. The route took him through Kalgoorlie, across the Nullarbor on [[Highway 1 (Australia)|Highway 1]] and through the Blue Mountains via Cowra. Prior to this journey James was an inexperienced runner, completing 3 marathons since 1999, and began his running training for this challenge in December 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamesbrooman.wordpress.com|title=Run Across Australia}}</ref>
===Tom Denniss=== Tom, who lives in Sydney, ran across Australia from Perth to Sydney in 2013. It was the final leg on his world circumnavigation run, which he commenced on New Year's Day, 2012, in Sydney. The trans-Australia leg was 97 days from June 10 to Sept 13, 2013, covering 5,000 km from Cottesloe Beach in Perth, to Kalgoorlie, Norseman, then across the Nullabor Plain, then Melbourne and finally Sydney, where he completed his world run on Friday, 13 September 2013. His circumnavigation totalled 26,232 km, the equivalent of 622 marathons in 622 days. This was the fastest ever circumnavigation of the Earth on foot, some 40 days quicker than Jesper Olsen’s earlier circumnavigation, a record which still stands (as at March 2016). Tom used his world run as an opportunity to raise funds for Oxfam, with over $50,000 raised throughout the journey.
===Jason P. Lester=== The first American male to run across Australia. Jason P. Lester's Trans Australia Run started in Scarborough Beach, Western Australia and ended 135 days later in Bateman's Bay, New South Wales. Lester ran 118 days, 2,633 miles, of which 2,000 miles were self supported pulling his gear in a 50 lb cart.
=== Greg Brown === Greg ran the East Coast of Australia from Cockle Creek on the South East Cape of Tasmania to the top of Cape York, Queensland following the coast as close as possible totalling 5,500km. He did it to raise money for The Cancer Council under the title of 'Cape to Cape for Cancer'. He started on the 2nd of April 2016, had the 7th of April off to catch the ferry across Bass Straight, then continuing along the coast to Cape York. Finishing on the 22nd of June 2016 only 82 days after starting.
=== Andre Jones === At the age of 56, Andre, who lives in Melbourne after serving 18 years in the Royal Australian Navy, ran solo and unsupported across Australia from Melbourne to Darwin in 93 days, between 10 March 2017 and 13 June 2017. In the 93 days, he took 9 days of rest (5 of which was to recover from an infected ant bite). From Melbourne, he travelled west to Adelaide then north to Darwin along the Stuart Highway via Port Augusta, Marla and Alice Springs, camping along the road when no other accommodation was available. Covering the approximately 3,700 km in the 84 running days, he averaged 44 km per day. As Andre was solo, he pushed the Intrepid (a custom made buggy) which carried his water, camping gear and supplies; when fully stocked it weighed as much as 95 kg. Andre used this journey to raise funds and awareness for beyondblue.
=== '''Richard Bowles''' === Richard Bowles cover the entire length of the Great Dividing Range, along Australia' Bicentennial National Trail at 5,330 km. He is the only person on his list to take his run 100% off road, taking on the Australia Alpine country and wading the Daintree River.
==See also== * [[Fundraising]] * [[List of people who have walked across Australia]] * [[Running]] * [[Twenty-first-century fundraising walks in Tasmania]] * [[Ultrarunning#Australia and New Zealand|Ultra-marathon running]]

The ''Nike Hypervenom'' is a [[football boot]] that is manufactured by [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]]. This type of boot is said to be for traction, power, and agility, designed for deceptive players. Therefore, it is endorsed/worn by players, notably [[Forward (association football)|forwards]], such as [[Robert Lewandowski]], [[Kylian Mbappé]], [[Harry Kane]], [[Edinson Cavani]], [[Gonzalo Higuaín]], [[Marcus Rashford]], [[Mauro Icardi]], [[Riyad Mahrez]], [[Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang|Aubameyang]] and [[Thiago Alcântara|Thiago]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Nike Hypervenom 3|url=https://news.nike.com/news/nike-hypervenom-3|website=Nike News|accessdate=October 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Nike Just Gave AS Monaco Sensation Kylian Mbappé His First Pair of Personalised Boots |url=https://www.complex.com/sports/2017/05/nike-kylian-mbappe |agency=Complex |date=29 June 2018}}</ref>
In May 2013, the ''Nike Hypervenom Phantom'' was launched. It was launched and designed for Brazilian forward [[Neymar]].<ref>{{cite web|title=New Nike Hypervenom boots launched by Neymar in Rio|url=https://www.t3.com/news/new-nike-hypervenom-boots-launched-by-barca-bound-neymar-in-rio|website=T3|accessdate=October 22, 2017|language=en}}</ref> The boot is currently in its third version. There is one high-end model for the first version, the ''Hypervenom Phantom''; whereas, there are two high-end models for the second version—the ''Nike Hypervenom Phantom II'', which is a mid-cut variant and the ''Nike Hypervenom Phinish'', the low-cut variant. However, Nike chose to discontinue the Nike Hypervenom Phinish from the third silo onwards due to confusion that the mid-cut version was better than the low-cut. The mid-cut version will be called "Hypervenom Phantom DF".<ref>{{cite web|title=Nike To Discontinue Nike Hypervenom Phinish Boots|url=http://www.footyheadlines.com/2016/11/nike-to-ditch-nike-hypervenom-phinish-boots.html?m=1|website=Footy Headlines|accessdate=October 22, 2017}}</ref>
The boot is available in Soft Ground (SG), Firm Ground (FG) or Artificial Ground (AG) versions in which all feature a glass nylon soleplate. There are also Turf (TF) and Indoor (IC) versions, in which the high-end model of these variants is the ''Nike HypervenomX Proximo''. The SG soleplate features 6 removable aluminium studs, in which different studs with different lengths can be used, and 6 fixed bladed studs. The FG version has 12 bladed and conical studs. The AG model contains many circular and hollow studs, meant to have more pressure distribution and trapping air to reduce impact and prevent injuries.
== Background == The ''Nike Hypervenom Phantom'' introduced several new features from other football boots at the time. It was made to replace the previous line, ''[[Nike Total 90]] (T90)'', a line from Nike that has been around since 2000. This decision was met with mixed feelings, in which some say it is a good decision to replace the older line, and the others saying it was not a beneficial idea, as there were not many 'power' boots on the market.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soccercleats101.com/2013/07/09/death-of-the-t90-birth-of-the-hypervenom/|title=Death of the T90, Birth of the Hypervenom!|last=Gauthier|first=Jim|date=2013-07-09|website=Soccer Cleats 101|access-date=2016-05-02}}</ref> The ''Hypervenom'' was launched in May 2013, with the [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] player, at the time, [[Neymar]], the main poster boy for this new line. The launch colourway was black/bright citrus. All boots were made in Soft Ground (SG), Firm Ground (FG) varieties, with the SG version using removable studs. The upper of the first boot has a newly developed material of ''NikeSkin.''<ref>{{cite web|last1=ha|first1=peter|title=Nike Hypervenom: It's Like Playing Soccer Barefoot|url=https://gizmodo.com/nike-hypervenom-its-like-playing-soccer-barefoot-510134745|website=Gizmodo|accessdate=October 22, 2017}}</ref>
== Hypervenom Phantom == The ''Hypervenom Phantom'' was released in May 2013. The boot was first known through a Nike commercial "Nike Hypervenom - Deadly Breed". Later on, more commercials will be made starring [[Neymar]] in which t''he video is counting down to the released date of the Hypervenoms. The boot are advertised to be for "fit, touch and traction". The boots are originally released in the black/bright'' citrus colourway.
The ''Hypervenom Phantom'' features a ''NikeSkin'' upper, combining mesh webbing and thin layers of polyurethane to create a material that is soft and flexible, ''All-Conditions Control (ACC)'' for the same control for any condition, whether wet or dry. The upper of the ''Hypervenoms'' is honeycomed-like in design. It also feature a lightweight, perforated anatomical sockliner for low-profile cushioning and has a responsive glass nylon chassis with agility traction stud pattern for agility, comfort and durability. Those who use these boots have said that they are able to move freely with ease and felt comfortable in those boots. However, some argue that it lacks proper tightness that they encounter issues such as roll-over or heel slippage. There are also some who said that the boots are not durable and lasted quite a short time under frequent use.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reviews.nike.com/9191/599843/nike-hypervenom-phantom-mens-firm-ground-soccer-cleat-reviews/reviews.htm|title=Nike Nike HYPERVENOM Phantom Men's Firm-Ground Soccer Cleat Reviews & Customer Ratings - Top & Best Rated Products|website=Nike|access-date=2016-05-02}}</ref>
During the knockout stages of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], following a 4–1 win over [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] in which Neymar scored the tournament’s 100th goal, Nike commemorated this with a special edition pair of ''Gold/Volt/Black'' ''Hypervenom'' boots. This was also made because Neymar spray painted his football boots gold when he was 12 years old.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/performance/football-boots/2014/06/nike-launch-neymar-hypervenom-goldvoltblack/|title=Nike Launch Gold Neymar HyperVenom : Football Boots : Soccer Bible|website=www.soccerbible.com|access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref>
In early 2015, the ''Liquid Diamond Hypervenom'' was released. It was made to help Neymar "stand out" in a match, to describe Neymar's energetic style of playing and the feelings that Neymar had to his sister was "rare, like diamonds" as stated in a Nike commercial.<ref>{{cite web|title=Neymar Jr. and Nike Introduce Hypervenom Liquid Diamond|url=https://news.nike.com/news/liquid-diamond|website=Nike News|accessdate=October 22, 2017}}</ref>
In mid-2015, the ''Hypervenom Phantom Transform SE'' was released. It features a special upper that changes from black to orange when heat is applied to it. This was the last edition of the ''Hypervenom Phantom I''.
== Hypervenom Phantom II/Hypervenom Phinish == Two years after the ''Hypervenom Phantom I'' was released, the new ''Hypervenom Phantom II'' and ''Hypervenom Phinish'' was released. This time, there were significant changes to the upper in terms of design and fit. The launch colourway is ''Wolf Grey/Total Orange/Black.''
=== Hypervenom Phantom II === The ''Hypervenom Phantom II'' is a mid-cut boot due to the ''Nike Dynamic Fit Collar'' which is made out of ''Flyknit'' said to provide ''ankle support''. As before, it has an ''ACC upper''. It also features a different ''NikeSkin'' upper from the previous version. One of the difference was the use of Nike's ''Flywire'' technology to provide a lock-in and tightened feel for a cleaner strike.
=== Change of upper === Due to the complaints about the new upper being too stiff, Nike opted to change the upper to the original ones on the Nike Hypervenom 1, effective 29 May 2016.
== Hypervenom III == In February 2017, Nike introduced the next generation of Hypervenom shoes with the Nike Hypervenom III. Nike did away with the Phinish and renamed that shoe 'Nike Hypervenom Phantom'. The collared shoe that had previously been known as the Nike Hypervenom Phantom is now the 'Nike Hypervenom Phantom DF' with the DF standing for Dynamic Fit referring to the collar. Nike have made noticeable aesthetic and construction alterations that make the Phantom III a different experience from the Phantom II.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.soccerpro.com/theinstep/nike-hypervenom-tier-breakdown-tell-differences/|title=Nike Hypervenom III Tier Breakdown - We Tell You The Differences - The Instep|date=2017-02-27|work=The Instep|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Hypervenom X == As the demand for urban football (street/cage football) is high, Nike created urban football boots using the same materials and/or design of their pitch football boots. The main difference in this line of Hypervenom is the use of gum rubber for the sole of the indoor and turf design.
[[File:HypervenomX Proximo.png|thumb|A pair of HypervenomX Proximo Indoor (IC), which has a flat gum rubber sole.]]
=== HypervenomX Proximo === The HypervenomX Proximo has exactly the same upper as the Hypervenom Phantom III. The only difference is use of a non-marking rubber sole for traction on indoor or turf courts and not including the PORON foam inserts
=== HypervenomX Finale === The HypervenomX Finale is the high-end low-cut model of the HypervenomX line. However, the upper is different compared to the upper used on the Hypervenom Phantom model. The upper is rather similar to the upper on the first version of the Hypervenom line, the Hypervenom Phantom 1. It also lacks ACC(All-Conditions Control). [[File:HypervenomX Finale Turf.jpg|thumb|The HypervenomX Finale Turf (TF) model, which has plenty of short gum rubber studs.]]
== See also == * [[Nike Tiempo]], Nike's "touch" boot * [[Nike Mercurial]], Nike's "speed" boot * [[Nike Magista]], Nike's "control" boot

[[Manila Metrostars]] (1998)
