[[Shakey's V-League]]
[[Manila Stars]] (2018–present) | former_names = Rizal Multi-Purpose Arena | seating_capacity = 6,000 | publictransit = {{rint|metro}} {{rint|manila|LRT-1}} {{lrt|Vito Cruz}} }} The '''Ninoy Aquino Stadium''' is one of two [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arenas]] located in the [[Rizal Memorial Sports Complex]] in [[Manila]], [[Philippines]], the other being the [[Rizal Memorial Coliseum]]. The arena is named after former [[Senator of the Philippines|Senator]] [[Benigno Aquino Jr.|Benigno S. Aquino Jr.]], commonly known as Ninoy Aquino. ==History== The venue was formerly an open-air stadium before being converted into a covered indoor arena. Formerly called the '''Rizal Multi-Purpose Arena''', the arena was renovated in time for the 1989 ABC Under-18 Championships hosted by the Philippines, which opened in January 24, 1989. At the opening of the tournament, the arena was renamed the '''Ninoy Aquino Stadium''' and a marker dedicating the arena was unveiled. The renovation included new chairs and a new scoring system from [[South Korea]] installed by Korean technicians.{{cite news|title=Mysterious no show by Youth cage|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g_oZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TgsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2175%2C564278|accessdate=15 June 2015|publisher=Manila Standard|date=4 January 1989}}{{cite news|title=Sin to bless cage site|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iPoZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TgsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2085%2C1404007|accessdate=15 June 2015|publisher=Manila Standard|date=9 January 1989}}{{cite news|title=It could have cost much less|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iY8VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=awsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5061%2C3667474|accessdate=15 June 2015|publisher=Manila Standard|date=22 March 1989}} The arena hosted the volleyball tournament of the [[1991 Southeast Asian Games]], The table tennis competitions of the [[2005 Southeast Asian Games]] and the [[2013 FIBA Asia Championship]] as the second venue of the tournament. It has also hosted mostly college basketball games such as the [[University Athletic Association of the Philippines|UAAP]], [[National Collegiate Athletic Association (Philippines)|NCAA]], [[National Capital Region Athletic Association|NCRAA]] and the [[National Athletic Association of Schools, Colleges and Universities|NAASCU]]. Currently, it is also known for hosting taekwondo tournaments, the two editions of the BSCP National Pool Championships and as one of the alternate venues of [[Philippine Basketball Association|PBA]] games. It was also the home court of the [[Manila Metrostars]] in the now-defunct [[Metropolitan Basketball Association]]. ==Notable events at the Ninoy Aquino Stadium== * 1989 ABC Under-18 Championship * [[Southeast Asian Games]] ([[1991 Southeast Asian Games|1991]] & [[2005 Southeast Asian Games|2005]]) * Hillsong United Live In Manila (2008) * [[Pinoy Big Brother: Double Up]] The Big Night * [[2009 Asian Men's Volleyball Championship]] * [[2010 MVP Invitational Champions' Cup]] * [[2013 FIBA Asia Championship]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Coord|14|33|51|N|120|59|28|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Sports venues in the Greater Manila Area}} {{2013 FIBA Asia Championship}} [[Category:Sports venues in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in the Philippines]] [[Category:Basketball venues in the Philippines]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Malate, Manila]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in the Philippines]] [[Category:Judo venues]] [[Category:Badminton in the Philippines]] [[Category:Badminton venues]] {{Philippines-sports-venue-stub}}

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Parade'' All-America Boys Basketball Team}} The '''''Parade'' All-America Boys Basketball Team''' was an annual selection by ''[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]'' that nationally honored the top high school boys' [[basketball]] players in the United States.{{cite news|title=Nominate a PARADE All-American|date=February 12, 2010|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|url=http://www.stltoday.com/sports/high-school/football/nominate-a-parade-all-american/article_a31297b2-724a-5cb3-b6b4-0c0669b6ed08.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XiMMywDy?url=http://www.stltoday.com/sports/high-school/football/nominate-a-parade-all-american/article_a31297b2-724a-5cb3-b6b4-0c0669b6ed08.html|archivedate=April 11, 2015|deadurl=no}} It was part of the [[Parade All-American|''Parade'' All-American]] series that originated with boys basketball before branching to other sports.{{cite web|title= Named to the PARADE All-American team|date=June 2003|work=milton.edu|url=http://www.milton.edu/news/All-American.cfm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528083054/http://www.milton.edu/news/All-American.cfm|archivedate=May 28, 2010|deadurl=no}} Started by the [[Sunday magazine]] in 1957, it had been the longest ongoing selection of high school basketball [[All-American]]s in the country at the time of its final selections in 2015.{{cite news|title=Melrose star and Memphis signee Adonis Thomas named PARADE All-American|date=March 28, 2011|newspaper=The Commercial Appeal|url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/melrose-star-and-memphis-signee-adonis-thomas-name|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Xqpby9ER?url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/melrose-star-and-memphis-signee-adonis-thomas-name|archivedate=April 17, 2015|deadurl=no}} Many of the honorees went on to star as [[college basketball|college]] and [[professional basketball]] players. As of March 2011, there were 162 ''Parade'' All-Americans that were playing in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA).{{cite news|title=Tony Wroten Jr. named to Parade All-America second team|date=May 28, 2011|newspaper=The Seattle Times|url=http://blogs.seattletimes.com/highschoolsports/2011/03/28/tony_wroten_jr_named_parade_al/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XiLMRR5v?url=http://blogs.seattletimes.com/highschoolsports/2011/03/28/tony_wroten_jr_named_parade_al/|archivedate=April 11, 2015|deadurl=no}} At its onset, the selections were handled by a New York-based public relations firm, Publicity Enterprises, which was led by [[Haskell Cohen]], who was a former sportswriter as well as the publicity director for the NBA at the time (1950–1969). The first All-America team in 1957 consisted of three five-player teams, and the first-team selections appeared on television on ''[[The Steve Allen Show]]''.{{cite news|last=Huff|first=Doug|title=EA SPORTS Boys & Girls All-Americans|work=yahoo.com|url=https://www.rivals.com/content.asp?SID=1132&CID=356222|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X2J21x11?url=https://www.rivals.com/content.asp?SID=1132&CID=356222|archivedate=March 15, 2015|deadurl=no}}{{cite book|last=Bell|first=Terry H. A.|title=Sweet Charlie, Dike, Cazzie, and Bobby Joe: High School Basketball in Illinois|page=74|year=2004|publisher=University of Illinois Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q2MZeXsUTPoC&lpg=PA74&ots=nsH0DxRjqP&dq=parade%20all-america%20%22steve%20allen%22&pg=PA74#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=April 17, 2015}} The following year, 20 players were selected and participated in the first annual ''Parade'' All-American high school game. The list later expanded to 40 of the nation's top players, divided into four teams of 10 each.{{cite news|title=Zeller named Parade All-American|date=April 4, 2008|newspaper=Washington Times Herald|url=http://www.washtimesherald.com/sports/zeller-named-parade-all-american/article_684a92c5-293f-515f-b6d1-3335deb27aa9.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XiKQtGXE?url=http://www.washtimesherald.com/sports/zeller-named-parade-all-american/article_684a92c5-293f-515f-b6d1-3335deb27aa9.html|archivedate=April 11, 2015|deadurl=no}} [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]], known then as Lew Alcindor, became the first sophomore in 1963 to be named a ''Parade'' All-American.{{cite news|title=The List: Best high school athletes ever|date=May 5, 2003|work=ESPN.com|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/highschool.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XjN51ibv?url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/highschool.html|archivedate=April 12, 2015|deadurl=no}} [[Earl Jones (basketball)|Earl Jones]] was the next to earn the distinction 15 years later as a sophomore,{{cite news|last=Jenkins|first=Chris|title=Prep Soph "Kareem" of the Crop|date=June 21, 1978|newspaper=Colorado Springs Gazette-Telegraph|page=1-C|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2221090/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate=April 15, 2015}}{{open access}} and subsequently joined Abdul-Jabbar as the first two players to be named to the first team on three occasions.{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Haskell|title=Parade's All-America High School Boys' Basketball Team|date=March 23, 1980|work=Parade|page=11|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xftLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RO4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3318%2C4329319|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} "It was a real thrill for me to make it on the ''Parade'' list early, when I was just a sophomore. The recognition is a great thing for kids to shoot for," said Abdul-Jabbar as part of the announcement for the 2000 team.{{cite book|title=Jordan Loveridge Named to PARADE's 56th Annual All-America Team|date=May 22, 2012|work=UtahUtes.com|url=http://www.utahutes.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/052212aaa.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XjNRnhG6?url=http://www.utahutes.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/052212aaa.html|archivedate=April 12, 2015|deadurl=no}} Starting in 2011, the selections were compiled in conjunction with ''[[Sporting News]]'' and their writer, Brian McLaughlin. Candidates also began to be limited to players in their senior year. The selections went to a single-team format in 2012, and the size was reduced from 40- to a 20-player first team in 2014.{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Brian|title=Escobar named Parade All-American in basketball|date=March 17, 2014|newspaper=Tallahassee Democrat|url=http://www.tallahassee.com/story/sports/preps/2014/03/16/escobar-named-parade-all-american-in-basketball-/6491273/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XrZfr1W2?url=http://www.tallahassee.com/story/sports/preps/2014/03/16/escobar-named-parade-all-american-in-basketball-/6491273/|archivedate=April 17, 2015|deadurl=no}} McLaughlin described the selections as mostly [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] college-bound players that had a stellar senior year in high school. Additionally, ''Parade'' differentiated itself from most other All-American teams by not focusing solely on a player's standing among [[college recruiter]]s. For example, some selectors might choose top recruits that had been injured much of their senior year.{{cite news|title=Brian McLaughlin|work=Parade|url=http://parade.com/member/brianmclaughlin/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XqWq6Ukw?url=http://parade.com/member/brianmclaughlin/|archivedate=April 17, 2015|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Ernie|title=Jonesport-Beals basketball standout Garet Beal named Parade All-American|date=May 24, 2013|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/05/24/sports/basketball/jonesport-beals-basketball-standout-garet-beal-named-parade-all-american/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XrajHkB7?url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/05/24/sports/basketball/jonesport-beals-basketball-standout-garet-beal-named-parade-all-american/|archivedate=April 17, 2015|deadurl=no}} ''Parade'' discontinued its boys' basketball All-America selections after 2015.{{cite tweet|author=Brian McLaughlin|user=BrianMacWriter|number=744234941341442048|date=June 18, 2016|title=@bigbluehistory Apparently a decision was made to discontinue those teams I am sad to report|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160709080057/https:/twitter.com/BrianMacWriter/status/744234941341442048|archivedate=July 9, 2016|deadurl=no}} ==Selections== {{inc-sport}} ===1957–1959=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:98%" |- !rowspan=2| Season !colspan=2| First team !colspan=2| Second team !colspan=2| Third team !colspan=2|Fourth team !rowspan=2|Ref |- !Player!!High school !Player!!High school !Player!!High school !Player!!High school |- |rowspan=5|

{{Infobox football club | clubname = RSSC United FC | image = RSSC United FC (logo).png | fullname =Royal Swaziland Sugar Corporation United FC | nickname = | founded = 2005 | ground = [[Mhlume Stadium]]
, [[Swaziland]] | capacity = | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Swazi Premier League]] | season = 2013–2014 | position = | }} '''Royal Swaziland Sugar Corporation United FC''' is a [[Swaziland|Swazi]] [[soccer]] club based in [[Mhlume]]. They play in the [[Swazi Premier League]].[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/swaziland/rssc-united/6063/matches Team results] – ''soccerway.com'' ==History== The team was found in 2005 by merging two teams [[Mhlume United]] and ''Simunye FC''.[http://www.weltfussballarchiv.com/club_profile.php?ID=15126 Team profile] – ''The Biggest Football Archive of the World'' ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the [[Mhlume Stadium]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/swaziland/rssc-united/6063 Team profile] – ''soccerway.com'' *{{facebook|rsscunited}} {{Swazi Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Eswatini]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2005]] {{Swaziland-footyclub-stub}}

'''Rocball''' is a non-contact [[Team sport|team]] net game derivative of [[volleyball]] and a [[Mesoamerica|Meso-American]] sport once played by the [[sportsperson|athlete]]s of the [[Aztec]] civilization of what is now the country of [[Mexico]]. Rocball has existed since 1979 and was founded by James Feger, a Physical Education teacher at Marianas High School located in The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The sports is getting popular in many Asian counties specially India. Delhi , the capital city of India is becoming epicenter of development of the game . Any volleyball court can be converted into a Rocball arena by simply placing two goalposts at two sides .
==Rules of the Sport== Rocball is played on a [[rectangular]] court bisected by an overhead net with [[Goal (sport)|goals]] located behind each end of the court.
The offensive team has the scoring advantage because of service and court points. However, either team has the opportunity to score from one to three points during any one play; under certain conditions, the defensive team can score one point plays, the server can score different types of two point plays, the [[Goalkeeper|goalies]] of either team can score two points, any player from either team can score a three-point goal, and there are different ways to win a set of play.
It is the first team net sport to implement offensive and defensive scoring, multiple point plays, plays in which a team can lose point, and the first team net sport to include the combination of [[kicking]] and hitting play action.
==RocBall jargon==
*''Court Point'' - the offensive team scores a point. *''Bogey Point'' - The offensive team loses a point. *''Jam'' - the defensive team scores a point. *''Face'' - the offensive or defensive team scores one point. *''Xunk'' - the defensive team loses two points. *''Ace'' - the offensive team scores two points. *''Kee'' - the offensive or defensive team scores two points *''Goal'' - a three-point play in which a team can add points to their own score or reduce their opponent's score. *''Juice-Out'' - the manner in which a team can win a game in four sets. *''O-Kon'' - Rocball overtime if neither team can Juice-Out in four sets. *''Blow-Out/Skunk/Scratch/Match'' - terms used to describe how teams win the different types of sets in Rocball
==Rocball in the Pacific== Rocball is popular in the island of Saipan, in Micronesia. it is also played in Asian countries such as Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, and Nepal.
==External links== *[http://www.saipan.com/business/rocball/ Information about Rocball]
[[Category:Ball games]]
{{ball-sports-stub}} www.rocball.com

08200 [[Sedan, Ardennes|Sedan]] | built= January 3, 2000 | opened = October 7, 2000 | expanded = 2001 | owner = Ville de Sedan | surface = Grass | construction_cost = 15,8 millions €[[Euro|EUR]] http://fsgiv.chez-alice.fr/stade/ | architect= Jean-Claude Paulin, Christophe Mariotti | tenants =[[Club Sportif Sedan Ardennes]] (2000-) | seating_capacity= {{formatnum:23,189}} http://www.lfp.fr/club/stade.asp?no_affil_fff=500266 | dimensions = 105 m x 68 m }} '''Stade Louis Dugauguez''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Sedan, France|Sedan]], [[France]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[CS Sedan Ardennes]]. The stadium holds 23,189 people and was built in 2000. It replaced [[Stade Emile Albeau]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|49.694147|4.938847|display=title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:6000}} [[Category:Football venues in France|Louis Dugauguez]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ardennes (department)]] [[Category:Sport in Champagne-Ardenne]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2000]] [[Category:2000 establishments in France]] {{France-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox video game |title = Turf |image = Official Turf logo.png |developer = Andrimon |platforms = [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] |released = 10th July 2010 |genre = [[massively multiplayer online game|massively multiplayer online]], [[location based game]] |director = Andreas Pantesjö
Simon Sikström }} '''''Turf''''' is a [[location based game|location based]] [[mobile game]] with [[Massively multiplayer online game|MMO]] and [[augmented reality]] elements developed by [[Sweden|Swedish]] video game developer Andrimon. It was released on 10 July 2010 for [[Android (operating system)|Android]], and later for [[iOS]]. The game was originally created by Andreas Pantesjö and Simon Sikström, who still actively maintain and develop the game.{{cite web|title=Turf - Outdoor addiction|url=https://turfgame.com/info/about|publisher=Andrimon|accessdate=16 July 2016}} The game has more than 150,000 registered players and is free to play. Players can pay a voluntary fee to receive "supporter" status, which gives access to additional in-app statistics, but comes with no gameplay benefits.{{cite web|title=Turf - Outdoor addiction, Supporter|url=https://turfgame.com/supporter|publisher=Andrimon|accessdate=16 July 2016}} The game has received media attention from Swedish, Finnish and Danish newspapers.{{cite web|title=Arnolds Bjerg erobret|url=http://sn.dk/Holbaek/Arnolds-Bjerg-erobret/artikel/295800|publisher=[[Sjællands Nyheder]]|date=19 March 2012|accessdate=27 July 2016|language=Danish}}{{cite web|title=Spelet som tar dig ut på cykeltur|trans-title=The game that takes you on a bicycle ride|url=http://gamla.hbl.fi/nyheter/2015-08-10/765876/spelet-som-tar-dig-ut-pa-cykeltur|author=Fanny Fröman|publisher=[[Hufvudstadsbladet]]|date=10 August 2015|accessdate=27 July 2016|language=Swedish}} == Gameplay == ''Turf'' combines elements from traditional [[orienteering]] with elements commonly seen in many video games, such as a leveling system, leaderboards and achievements. The goal is to collect points by capturing virtual zones using the built-in GPS system of modern smartphones, and try to keep them for as long as possible to compete with other players. Zones are located all over the world, but with the highest concentration in countries with active competition, such as [[Sweden]], [[Finland]] and [[Denmark]]. Zones are most commonly taken by foot or by bicycle, but occasionally zones are captured by other means, such as by boat and by car. ''Turf'' is by many players used as an [[exergaming|exergame]], a way of combining exercise with gaming.{{cite web|title=Han har cyklat minst 2000 mil på två år|trans-title=He has traveled at least 2,000 miles by bicycle over the course of two years|url=http://vlt.se/kulturnoje/1.3079357-han-har-cyklat-minst-2000-mil-pa-tva-ar|publisher=[[Vestmanlands Läns Tidning]]|date=23 July 2015|accessdate=16 July 2016|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Mobilspelet som håller dig aktiv|trans-title=The mobile game that keeps you active|url=http://norran.se/livsstil/mobilspelet-som-haller-dig-aktiv-425384|publisher=[[Norran]]|date=21 July 2015|accessdate=16 July 2016|language=Swedish}} It has also been compared with augmented reality games ''[[Ingress (video game)|Ingress]]'' and ''[[Pokémon Go]]''.{{cite web|title=Efter Pokémon Go – rusning till svensk föregångare|trans-title=After Pokémon Go - rush towards Swedish predecessor|url=http://digital.di.se/artikel/efter-pokemon-go--rusning-till-svensk-foregangare|author=Daniel Goldberg|publisher=[[Dagens Industri]]|date=29 July 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016|language=Swedish}} == Game rounds == ''Turf'' is played in rounds that each last for a month. Collected points by the player reset when a new round starts, as well as all ownership of the zones in the game. Total accumulated points by the player never reset after a round ends, as these are used to determine a player's rank as well as provide useful statistics for players to track their progress. At the end of a round the winner may choose to create a unique, custom zone anywhere, often referred to as a "winner zone". == Events == There are special events arranged when players gather in a city to compete. A major annual event is called a ''Bonanza'', where participants gather in a city and run a standalone game session that lasts for a couple hours. Bonanzas are characterized by dense placement of zones in a game environment separate from the regular game to make the contest a standalone championship. The first Bonanza organized for [[Djurgården]] in [[Stockholm]], Sweden, on 21 May 2011. In 2016, it was held in [[Kalmar]].{{cite web|title=Hundratals deltagare väntas till "Turf-VM"|trans-title=Hundreds of participants expected for the "Turf world championships"|url=http://www.barometern.se/kalmar/hundratals-deltagare-vantas-till-turf-vm/|publisher=[[Barometern]]|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=20 July 2016|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Turfare jagade mobilzoner i Kalmar|trans-title=Turfers hunted mobile zones in Kalmar|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=86&artikel=6437879|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]]|date=23 May 2016|accessdate=16 July 2016|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Västeråsare anordnar turf-bonanza i helgen|trans-title=People in Västerås are arranging a Turf Bonanza this weekend|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=112&artikel=5249543|author=Natalie Caballero Löf|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]]|date=29 August 2012|accessdate=17 July 2016|language=Swedish}} Other, smaller, events also occur that are similar to the major annual Bonanza event. They can be situated in different places with different orientations ([[canoe]],{{cite web|title=Turfande kanotister intog Malmfjärden|trans-title=Turf-playing canoers captured Malmfjärden|url=http://www.barometern.se/kalmar/turfande-kanotister-intog-malmfjarden/|author=Peter Karlsson|publisher=[[Barometern]]|date=30 August 2015|accessdate=20 July 2016|language=Swedish}} only by foot, long seclusion etc.) In 19 June 2011, one of the first ''Turf'' events was at [[Dreamhack]] in Sweden.{{cite web|title=TURF @ Dreamhack|url=http://www.dreamhack.se/DHS11/2011/06/16/turf-dreamhack|publisher=[[Dreamhack]]|accessdate=17 July 2016|language=English}} An event can also be a closed event where only the invited have access, with small groups such as school physical education. In 2016, more than 300 physical education lessons consisted of "orientation" of the Turf. == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.turfgame.com}} * [http://wiki.turfgame.com/sv/wiki/Media Turf articles in media (in Swedish)] [[Category:2010 video games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Exergames]] [[Category:Free-to-play video games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Location-based games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Sweden]]

[[HC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] }} '''CSKA Arena''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|ЦСКА Арена}}){{Cite web|url=http://cska-hockey.ru/news/Novosti_kluba/dvorets_v_parke_legend_poluchit_nazvanie_tsska_arena/|title=VTB Ice Palace gets a new name, CSKA Arena|publisher=cska-hockey.ru|lang=ru|accessdate=2018-08-09}}, formerly known as '''VTB Ice Palace''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|ВТБ Ледовый дворец}}) and '''Legends Arena''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Арена Легенд}}), is an indoor multi-sport venue that is located in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. Its main sponsor is [[VTB]]. The facility features 3 different indoor arenas, the "Large Arena", the "Small Arena", and a training facility, all housed in the same complex. Both the large and small arenas are multi-purpose venues. CSKA Arena is a part of the Park of Legends big renovation project, on the site of the former [[ZiL]] auto plant. It includes the Arena, the Russian Hockey Museum with the Russian Hockey Hall of Glory, Watersport Arena, and Apartments Complex. It is located near by the [[ZIL (Moscow Central Circle)|ZIL]] MCC and [[Avtozavodskaya (Zamoskvoretskaya Line)|Avtozavodskaya]] Metro station. ==Venues== The large arena has a [[seating capacity]] of 12,100 viewers for [[ice hockey]] and [[figure skating]], 13,000 for [[basketball]]{{Cite web |url=http://parklegends.ru/news/rukovoditeli-evroligi-i-cska-posetili-arenu-legend |title=РУКОВОДИТЕЛИ ЕВРОЛИГИ И ЦСКА ПОСЕТИЛИ "АРЕНУ ЛЕГЕНД" |language=ru |access-date=September 16, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123213814/http://parklegends.ru/news/rukovoditeli-evroligi-i-cska-posetili-arenu-legend |archive-date=November 23, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} and 14,000 for [[wrestling]], [[boxing]], [[Mixed martial arts|MMA]], and [[concerts]]. The large arena also has 80 VIP luxury box suites. The small arena has a [[seating capacity]] of 3,500 viewers for [[ice hockey]] and [[figure skating]], 4,400 for [[basketball]] and 5,000 for [[wrestling]], [[boxing]], [[Mixed martial arts|MMA]], and [[concerts]]. The third arena, the training arena, has a capacity of 500.{{Cite web |url=http://parklegends.ru/object/vtb-ledovyj-dvorec/mnogofunkcionalnyj-kompleks-vtb-ledovyj-dvorec |title=ВТБ ЛЕДОВЫЙ ДВОРЕЦ |language=ru |access-date=September 16, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923010415/http://parklegends.ru/object/vtb-ledovyj-dvorec/mnogofunkcionalnyj-kompleks-vtb-ledovyj-dvorec |archive-date=September 23, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ==History== The Ice Palace opened on April 26, 2015. From 2015 till 2018 it was the home stadium for the [[Kontinental Hockey League]] ice hockey team [[HC Dynamo Moscow|Dynamo Moscow]] In 2015, five of six matches of [[2015 Channel One Cup|Channel One Cup]] were played in the Arena. In 2016, the arena hosted games of the [[2016 IIHF World Championship]]. Since 2018 it became the home stadium for [[HC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]]. == Gallery == 2015 C1C - VTB Ice Palace inside panorama.jpg|850px|center|Channel One Cup (Sector 202) IIHF16WC - NOR v KAZ panorama.jpg|850px|center|2016 IIHF World Championship (Sector 212) Former ZIL area Moscow asv2018-01 img5.jpg|Aerial photo of former ZiL plant, Moscow (2018) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat inline}} *{{Official website|http://parklegends.ru/}} {{ru icon}} {{KHL Arenas}} {{IIHF World Championship venues}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Russia]] [[Category:Boxing venues in Russia]] [[Category:HC Dynamo Moscow]] [[Category:Dynamo Moscow|Sports venue]] [[Category:IIHF World Championship venues]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Russia]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Russia]] [[Category:Kontinental Hockey League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2015]] [[Category:Sports venues in Moscow]] [[Category:2015 establishments in Russia]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Victor Tedesco Stadium | nickname = | image = Victor Tedesco Stadium.jpg | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Ħamrun]], [[Malta]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1996 | renovated = 2008 (new pitch) | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Ħamrun Spartans F.C.|Ħamrun Spartans]]https://www.mfa.com.mt/en/news/news/1202/il-victor-tedesco-stadium-approvat-fifa-2-star.htm | operator = [[Ħamrun Spartans F.C.|Ħamrun Spartans]] | surface = [[Artificial turf]] | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Ħamrun Spartans F.C.|Ħamrun Spartans]] | capacity = 1,962http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2012-10-29/news/sanctioning-of-upgrading-at-victor-tedesco-stadium-approved-297566256/ | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} The '''Victor Tedesco Stadium''' is a stadium in [[Ħamrun]], [[Malta]]. It opened in 1996. It has a capacity of 6,000, with 1,800 seated. It is the home ground of Maltese football club [[Ħamrun Spartans F.C.|Ħamrun Spartans]], who currently play in the [[Maltese Premier League]]. It is used for matches from the Maltese Premier League, the Maltese First Division, and some games from the Maltese Second Division. It is also used by all the [[Ħamrun Spartans]] teams from the youth teams to the senior teams for training. The stadium also has a bar, underground dressing rooms, some offices, and a five-a-side pitch next door. On 4 June 2010 [[rugby league]] was played at the ground. The [[Malta national rugby league team|Malta Knights]] came from 10–0 down midway through the first half to defeat Norway, 30–20 to win the Rugby League European Federation Bowl. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Geographic coordinate system|Coordinates]]: {{Coord|35.887349|N|14.492514|E|type:landmark}} [[Category:Football venues in Malta]] [[Category:Hamrun Spartans F.C.]] [[Category:Ħamrun]] {{Malta-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = William H. Detrick Gymnasium | nickname = | image =William H. Detrick Gymnasium.jpg | location = 1615 Stanley Street
[[New Britain, Connecticut]] 06053 | broke_ground = | opened = 1965 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Central Connecticut State University | operator = Central Connecticut State University | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost= | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Central Connecticut State University|Central Connecticut State Blue Devils]]
(NCAA Sports) | seating_capacity = 2,654 }} '''William H. Detrick Gymnasium''' is a 2,654-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[New Britain, Connecticut]]. It is home to the [[Central Connecticut State University]] Blue Devils [[basketball]] [[team]]. It opened in 1965 and the first game was played on December 4 against [[Coast Guard Bears|Coast Guard]].{{cite web|title=CCSU Celebrates 50th Anniversary of the First Basketball Game at Kaiser Hall|url=http://northeastconference.org/news/2015/12/4/MBB_KaiserHall_50th_CCSU_15.aspx|publisher=NortheastConference.org|accessdate=9 December 2015}} In 2005 it received a new floor, the first since the facility opened its doors in 1965.http://www.ccsubluedevils.com/facilities/detrick/index The [[Northeast Conference]] men's basketball tournament was held there in 1998, 2002, and 2007. The facility is named after [[Bill Detrick]], who was head coach at CCSU for 29 years, compiling a school-record 468 wins.{{cite web| last = Anthony | first = Mike | title = Bill Detrick, Longtime Central, Trinity Coach, Dead At 87 | work = [[Hartford Courant]] | url = http://www.courant.com/sports/college/hc-bill-detrick-ccsu-dead-0920-20140919-story.html#page=1 | date = September 19, 2014 | accessdate = October 11, 2014}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{CSUS}} {{Central Connecticut Blue Devils men's basketball navbox}} {{Central Connecticut Blue Devils women's basketball}} {{Northeast Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{coord|41.693|-72.7649|display=title}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Connecticut]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hartford County, Connecticut]] [[Category:Central Connecticut Blue Devils men's basketball]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Connecticut]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1965]] {{Connecticut-stadium-stub}}
